Title: "Enabling Semantic Ranking in Azure Search: A Step-by-Step Guide"
Text:
C:\Users\adamh\Downloads\azure-search.pdf"genre": 5,            "artistName": 2          }        }      },      {        "name": "newAndHighlyRated",        "functions": [          {            "type": "freshness",            "fieldName": "lastUpdated",            "boost": 10,            "interpolation": "quadratic",            "freshness": {              "boostingDuration": "P365D"            }          },          {          "type": "magnitude",            "fieldName": "rating",            "boost": 10,            "interpolation":
"linear",            "magnitude": {              "boostingRangeStart": 1,              "boostingRangeEnd": 5,              "constantBoostBeyondRange": false            }          }        ]      }    ],    "suggesters": [      {        "name": "sg",        "searchMode": "analyzingInfixMatching",        "sourceFields": [ "albumTitle", "artistName" ]      }    ]   }  See alsoEnable or disable semantic rankingArticle•11/15/2023Semantic ranking is a premium feature that's billed by usage.
By default, semanticranking is disabled on all services.Follow these steps to enable semantic ranking at the service level. Once enabled, it'savailable to all indexes. You can't turn it on or off for specific indexes.1. Open the Azure portal.2. Navigate to your search service. The service must be a billable tier.3. Determine whether the service region supports semantic ranking:a. Find your service region in the overview page in the Azure portal.b. Check the Products Available by Region page on the Azure web site tosee if your region is listed.4. On the left-nav pane, select Semantic ranking.5. Select either the Free plan or the Standard plan. You can switch between thefree plan and the standard plan at any time.Enable semantic rankingAzure portalThe free plan is capped at 1,000 queries per month.
